abstract.text: The Global Calculator (GC) can be used to assess a wide range of climate change mitigation pathways. The GC is an 13 accessible integrated model which calculates the cumulative emissions of a basket of the main greenhouse gases that 14 result from a set of technological and lifestyle choices made at the global level and as defined by the user within a 15 single system dynamics tool. Using the GC, we simulated ambitious scenarios against business as usual trends in order 16 to stay below 2 o C and 1.5 o C of maximum temperature change by the end of this century and carried out a sensitivity 17 analysis of the entire GC model option space. We show that the calculator is useful for making broad simulations for 18 energy, carbon and land use dynamics, and demonstrate how combined and sustained mitigation efforts across 19 different sectors are urgently needed to meet climate targets.

body_text.text: The Global Calculator 1 (GC) is a pioneering initiative aimed at informing the climate debate at the international level, 23 by providing a relatively simple and highly accessible systems tool for policy makers, business leaders, NGOs and econometric model or a profit-optimization model. Optimisation functionality is instead passed to the user who makes 88 combinations of choices and is immediately shown the impacts arising from that set of choices (a pathway). The 89 calculator also provides a novel approach to assess energy demand and supply dynamics. The user begins by defining 90 or setting levels of core 'activities' (e.g., the amount of protein-rich food eaten, the distance travelled, the level of 91 heating and cooling needed for residential and commercial buildings), and then choses (and setting) the food, transport 92 and building solutions that enable those activities (or services) to be provided. For example, once these choices are 93 made, the overall demand for food is calculated and defines the impacts on land resources given the set of 94 technological choices for the provision of the food as made by the end-user (or as default settings under a given pre-95 defined pathway). All the pathways available will be defined by the set of services (activities) demanded and the 96 associated products (fertilisers, cars, houses and windmills) needed to supply those services, which in turn, are 97 manufactured with associated demand for resources (fuels, minerals, biomass, etc.) calculated. All activities, services 98 and product provision use energy which needs to be produced, transported and stored. Finally, both energy demand 99 and supply use fuel resources. This enables the model to be used to assess the impact of both behavioural (e.g., eating 100 and heating habits, modal switching in transport) and technological changes (e.g., electric vehicles, renewable energy 101 (wind, PV, hydro and biomass) and product innovation). To become operational, the calculator deploys a number of representative levers, which are all interconnected as a 106 broad integrated system that may vary over time. FIGREF5.text: Business as Usual 6 o C 149 Our baseline 6 o C scenario ('BAU') is the default pathway set in the GC. It simulates a low mitigation pathway by 150 2050, and is similar to the scenario provided by the IEA [9] that would lead to a global temperature increase of 6 o C (its 151 'IEA6DS' example pathway). The approximate representation of this scenario in the calculator was developed in 152 collaboration with IEA staff. Despite the BAU being considered as a pessimistic scenario, it still contains some level 153 of low mitigation efforts and technology improvements, including limited residential building sizes as well as some 154 improvements in home energy use efficiency, particularly in lighting and appliances and, from the land-use side, 155 agricultural and livestock practices such as the management and use of agricultural residues. The rest of the levers are 156 set with moderate level of mitigation ambition with the lowest ambition being placed in commercial building 157 efficiency as well as in carbon capture and storage technologies.

The global economy is then able to meet 20-30% of its energy 248 requirements with bioenergy and waste, according to its climate ambition. Other renewable sources also show a 249 remarkable increase when moving from the 6 o C to the 2 o C scenario. Solar, wind, wave and tidal energy increase 250 substantially, from 2% of the energy supply to 17%. Nevertheless, augmenting the ambition to the 1.5-degree pathway 251 target does not change their share substantially, except for bioenergy, with a significant increase in the global energy 252 mix. This pathway requires dietary changes of the global population, reducing the need for agricultural and 253 pasturelands to meet global food demand by 2050 and, therefore, freeing up more lands for the expansion of energy 254 crops, without challenging food security. These simulations show the importance of the land use sector for the 308 climate agenda which is often neglected. This sector can move from a source of positive GHG emissions to a net 309 carbon removal option, as also recently demonstrated by Strapasson et al. [2]. FIGREF23.text: Results from the sensitivity analysis314    The results from the sensitivity analysis of the GC are shown inFigure 10. The impact of exclusive changes to the 315 levels of each lever compared to BAU in 2050, in terms of avoided emissions, are provided, as previously described in316 Methods (Section 2). Variations between levels 3 and 4 represent an extreme level of action, although still technically 317 possible. The levers related to diet and food production have the largest effects on GHG emissions. However, changes 318 in diet are related to lifestyle and cultural aspects and hence is considered likely to generate high levels of inertia 319 compared to BAU. A reduction in per capita meat consumption, especially beef, is calculated to reduce the demand 320 from pastureland and croplands for producing animal feed, freeing up land resources for other purposes, such as 321 afforestation/reforestation and the expansion of energy crops, both with substantial GHG savings. On the other hand, if 322 dietary patterns are kept at BAU levels, then increases in livestock and associated resource use efficiency, particularly 323 by increasing the global average number of ruminant animals per hectare (animal density on pasturelands), could also 324 free up land resources for other purposes. However, increasing fossil fuel use efficiency is also a key strategy for 325 reducing GHG emissions, as well as changes in global population, and other high impact levers. Some levers may not 326 show significant impacts depending on the level of ambition for carbon mitigation. For example, geothermal energy is 327 not deployed significantly in levels 1 and 2, but it is required when adopting levels 3 and 4. Sensitivity analysis of lever settings, regarding emissions reductions in the Global Calculator, with varying 330 levels of mitigation effort against the BAU scenario (6ºC) by 2050, in GtCO 2 eq per year.

For 333 instance, the diet lever is related to a behavioural change rather than a technological innovation. Meat consumption, 334 particularly, has a very broad range of mitigation efforts: level 1 represents a pessimistic scenario with a substantial335 increase in global meat consumption with levels of consumption that are similar to those currently observed in the 336 European Union, i.e. much above global trends, which are more aligned with level 2, calibrated based on trends 337 suggested by the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) [12]. Setting level 3 results in a gradual reduction in 338 per capita meat consumption towards the 90g of meat per day suggested as a healthy level of consumption by the 339 World Health Organization (WHO) [13], and level 4, an extreme reduction is assumed, analogous to current per capita 340 meat consumption rates in India, where the majority of the population adopt a vegetarian diet. These changes have 341 major implications for GHG emissions, not only by reducing emissions from enteric fermentation of ruminant animals, 342 but also by allowing the expansion of forests and energy crops on freed-up land (aka surplus lands), with implications 343 also in terms of soil carbon balances, and even public health [14]. Such abrupt changes in global dietary patterns have 344 no precedent in recent history, yet they are assessed to be technically possible enabling their inclusion in the GC. Thus, 345 the interpretation of the sensitivity analysis requires an understanding of the assumptions behind each lever's level, 346 which are all described in the GC web tool and its supplementary documents. 347 Figure 11 shows the impact of each sector on global GHG emissions. Each mitigation pathway simulates changes only up to 2050 and some technologies 398 may take longer to become feasible or to become costly competitive against conventional technologies. Take, for 399 example, the case of fusion energy, which is not included in the calculator, but may potentially become a major source400 of energy after 2050, as well as disruptive innovations such as artificial meat, and the emergence of many unexpected 401 technologies, including carbon dioxide removal. Hence, the GC provides estimates for a broad range of carbon 402 mitigation pathways, but it is still constrained by current knowledge of future technological potentials and climate 403 dynamics.

There are several uncertainties in 441 the GC, which arise from a model aimed at making broad simulations for all sectors of the economy combined with a 442 relatively simple interface designed to enable its use by policy makers, business leaders, NGOs and researchers. The 443 cost analysis, in particular, would be better represented if cost estimates for individual pathways could be compared to 444 potential adaptation costs of not acting to curb carbon emissions. The GC also 128 carries out approximate cost simulations by using the UCL TIAM model, and includes an original land use sub-model 129 [2]. Another important difference between the global and national versions is that the global model allows us to 130 estimate the expected temperature change by 2100, providing a visual thermometer with a distribution bar on the web 131 tool, as well as a bar graph which displays the cumulative emissions and the 50% chance to stay below 2 o C or 1.5 o C 132 target. To estimate temperature potentials, the calculator uses the projected cumulative emissions obtained from the 133 model, and uses the methodology of the International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) [7], as derived from several 134 climate simulation models for temperature change (see the climate tab of the GC web tool and its supporting online 135 documentation). Moreover, linking the lever ambitions to economics was recently assessed in the European Calculator, whereas linking the lever ambitions to policies has been assessed by Climact and NewClimate for the European Climate Change Foundation within the Climate Transparency Initiative.

Moreover, the GC does not provide options for simulating the effects of carbon taxes or price elasticities regarding the adoption of different technologies and fuels, given that it is not an econometric model. On the other hand, this was not the aim of the GC, and this can be potentially complemented by other types of existing and future models, such as agent-based models, networks, and game theory models. The Financial Times' Calculator, as already cited in the Introduction (Section 1), does provide some simulations at country level, although only for major emitters. Several countries have their own national 2050 calculators (as also mentioned in the Introduction) and a similar assessment to this article was already performed for some them, such as for the Mexico 2050Calculator [16]  and the European Calculator[17], which does offer simulations at country level for its 28-Member States (EU-28).Another important observation is that the current version of the GC (version 23) does not include feedback-looping effects for assessing the impacts of climate change according to different carbon emissions trajectories, such as an increase in climate vulnerabilities (e.g. impacts on crop yields due to changes in temperature and rainfall) and adaptation costs (e.g. due to sea level rise in the coastal areas and to an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events) by 2050. Moreover, biodiversity and water balance issues were not directly covered in the GC, but some related variables were included in the recently published European Calculator.The GC is able to simulate a very large number of climate change mitigation pathways, as well as changes in the global energy mix and land use. The suggested distributed efforts for meeting the 2 o C and 1.5 o C targets show that these targets are still possible to be achieved, but that success in achieving them will require urgent and very substantial levels of effort across all sectors of the global economy. These simulations are illustrative pathways among many other possibilities that the world could take towards reducing GHG emissions. For example, the GC also allows simulations to be made that are focused on a higher use of solar photovoltaic systems and electric vehicles, with these highly cost effective technologies taking up a large share of the global energy supply, in a similar context to the analysis recently made bySussams et al. [18]  for disruptive changes in technology. Some other examples are pathways that are focused on dietary patterns and land use[2], and on sustainable transport systems in cities[3]. In addition, the calculator can compare carbon mitigation pathways to approximate representations of the IPCC's Representative Concentration Pathways (RCP), providing useful insights for climate change analysts.The sensitivity analysis of the GC shows that there is no 'silver bullet' for carbon mitigation by 2050, demonstrating the contribution of each sector for reducing GHG emissions.
